bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to George A. Kellogg, March 21, 1941

div1.p: Hench thinks Kellogg handled the Cuban situation well. He comments on the Finlay supporters in Cuba. Hench discusses the Cornwell painting in progress and the suggestions Kellogg has received from various men concerning the painting.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to George A. Kellogg, March 21, 1941
div1.opener:
Yellow
Fever
March 21, 1941
Mr. George A. Kellogg
257 Cornelison Avenue
Jersey City, New Jersey
My dear Mr. Kellogg:
div1.p:
I was most interested in the various letters, copies of which you
sent me. They were illuminating and helpful. I think you handled very well the
delicate situation proposed by your Cuban representative. I have Dr. Dominguez's
book - he is the most rabid of the pro-Finlay Cubans. I met him and he gave me
his book. He is so rabidly pro-Finlay that he has become not a scientist but
merely a propagandist. He is, by the same token, rabidly anti-Reed and so forth.
General Kean has corresponded with me about it and tells me it is filled with
mistakes, although of course it has much truthful and interesting data in it. I
read French only so so, enough to get the drift but not with sufficient case that
I could trust my own translation and use it as a basis for criticizing a man's
statements. Therefore, I repeatedly asked Domingues for the English translation
which he told me about, told him I wanted to do full justic to Finlay (which I
most certainly do) and therefore, wanted the Finlay version. But he stalled me
off without adequate explanation. And you now give me the answer--apparently
he considers it in poor shape for current publication.

Personally, I would very much like to see a copy and see it published
but I quite agree that you shouldn't get mixed up in it. It might keephelp you in Cuba
but not in the United States. I can't understand why he and his colleagues seem
to need outside help to push its publication. Last year I understood the government
was about to publish it and hand it out free. I asked Ramos for a copy but he said
it “wasn't ready.” But they are all filled with such fanatical zeal in behalf of
Finlay that I wouldn't think Dominguez needed outside help. Perhaps Ramos and other
higher up see a fight ahead and don't feel sure enough to start shooting. It's
all so silly and so sad. For Finlay Was a great man and they do him an injustice
to inflat him beyond recognition.

I will be very pleased to receive the photos of the Cuban version
and cwill certainly try to get some constructive criticism and get their reaction.
I do not think the Cuban sketches are wasted. I still hope you can fix them up for
Cuban exhibition unless a majority of Cubans were to criticize the details of the
get-up as seriously as did Miss Agramonte. Let me repeat, if you really want me
to show the colored ones to the Cubans, I'll do it and you can ship them to your
Cuban representative or addressed to me at the Hotel Nacional.

I will drop you a line from Havana, or perhaps from Palm Beach before
and after I go to Havana March 27 or 28 for one week. My Palm Beach address will
be Villa Atlantique Hotel - March 23 to April 16 or 17. I shall let you know more
about our New York stopover later. I certainly would like to see the sketches of
the American version and meet Mr. Cornwell. By the way, who were the two sitting
figures in the Cuban version - Delgado and who?

I still think my suggestion about the American version is better
than to have, as you call it, a “mob-scene.” I agree that it would be nice to have
a formal group portrait of all concerned but there would be no life - no advertising
value - no action in it. Also, General Kean has confessed that he likes the idea
of General Truby but likes his own idea better - a portrait of Reed getting General
Wood's permission. It was apparently a dramatic moment and General Kean was the
only other one present. Naturally he recalls it with gusto but as he admitted,
Lazear et al were not there and hence that scene is inappropriate. I am still a
little worried about having the experiment on the lawn: That aren't scientific:
But with the others, I agree that the artist must have some license. I'm sure that
99 per cent will be pleased with the result especially if you stick to the “big
five” (Finlay, Reed, Carroll, Lazear, Agramonte). When you start adding others you
will get into trouble. I quite agree hearily that it would be a fine thing to
have Moran and Kissinger in it, but only as “representative” of the band of soldier-
volunteers and on the little descriptive folder you should say definitely that they
are in it as “representatives” and then give the names (I can supply them). Beyond
that I would not go unless you want an unidentified female figure for relief. I'll
ask Moran and Albertini if Miss Maas was around (or any other female nurses) when
Lazear and Carroll were doing their phase of the work.

I thought your letters from Moran and Truby very nice. I was amused
at Doctor Cumming's expression that you were “smoking a cigarette around a keg of
gunpowder.” Last year I too rushed in, not knowing anything about the depths of the
controversy. But I still say if you in your medium and I in mine, portray the truth,
our work will live and stand and the hell with anything else. Don't let anything
or anybody discourage you or stop you. It will be a grand, perhaps a great,
picture and if it is true it will live as the representation of the truth about
those who conquered yellow fever. Cummings, I see, has his favorites and wants
Carter and Manson and perhaps Roas in it. Yo gods, who not include the whole
American army of intervention and have a scene like one of those French battle scenes
by Detaille or Meissonier:.

I was distressed to see poor old John Kissinger's letter. He must
be failing. It still breathes some pep and meal, still the same (proper) adoration
of Reed but I thought I had closed the breech between him and Moran. Apparently
he doesn' understand why I've spent so much time in Cuba. He must think I'm just
getting Moran's version that he and Kissinger volunteered together with Moran as
spokesman rather than believing Kissinger's version that Kissinger volunteered a
day or so ahead of Moran. I don't know which is correct but intend to find out
from official sources not dependant on memory. So don't worry about Kissinger's
letter, I'll make the old fellow happy yet:

I will appreciate it if you will continue to send me such
carbons and photostats as will be interesting and helpful. I am certainly glad to
know about the Dominguez affair for I might have gotten mixed up in it myself.
div1.closer: Sincerely yours, P. S. Hench, M. D. PSH:FP
